title: Kenya: Borrow for Investment Not Recurrent Needs
text:
Kenya: DP Ruto to Wait Longer for Trial to Resume 
However, the government must take great care not to convert the Japan International Co-operation Agency loan for the healthcare sector into financing recurrent expenditure. This would be unsustainable and unrealistic. 
Kenya shouldn't borrow for recurrent expenditure in any sector, not health only. The National Treasury must not borrow to pay doctors' and nurses' salaries and allowances but it can prudently borrow to build more wards, clinics, dispensaries and hospitals. 
The cost of borrowing to meet recurrent expenditure is invariably not worth the effort. 
The JICA loan comes in a package that includes the vast Mombasa Port Development Phase II project, a medical waste and hazardous waste appropriate processing plant and non-project grant aid for provision of Japanese SME products. 
Prudent borrowing must go towards capital investment, which involves one-off long-term projects that transform lives.
